document_title: What is posterior migraine? Causes, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
Posterior migraines caused by stress can often be treated at home; However, if the cause of posterior migraine comes from other medical conditions, you need to see a doctor immediately to be examined and rule out underlying medical causes.
The treatment of posterior headaches requires a combination of many measures. Patients need to see a doctor for appropriate diagnosis and treatment, combined with home support. Specifically:
Maximum relaxation: Rest and sleep on time for at least 7 hours/day (as recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for adults 18 years and older). (5); Eat scientifically: Drink 2 liters of water a day, eat enough sleep, don't skip meals and get enough nutrients.; Relaxation therapy: Practice meditation or gentle exercises to relax muscle groups in the head, neck, shoulders and back. Yoga or pilates may be helpful. Besides, massage therapy or acupuncture therapy in the head area at the painful location to improve blood circulation is also a good choice.; Using medication: Popular over-the-counter pain relievers such as Panadol, Paracetamol, Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen or Aspirin can quickly relieve post-migraine symptoms.; Follow your doctor's orders: Go for check-ups and follow-up appointments on time, and follow your doctor's prescriptions. Consult your doctor before using over-the-counter pain relievers to ensure effective treatment.
Besides, if you think poor posture may be the cause, improve your posture:
Correct back shape: Sit straight in a chair when using a computer, use a back cushion to support, avoid sagging in the lower back.; Correct your neck shape: Adjust the screen to eye level. Do not bend your neck or stretch your neck too close to the screen.; Reduce muscle tension: Take regular breaks to help reduce muscle tension from continuous computer typing.
See more: What is frontal migraine? The cause and how to fix it.
